337.text: Well, obviously not. It would be absurd

498.text: we need to get away from instrumental arguments.

501.text: We need to get away from saying democracy matters

505.text: because of the other things it brings.

508.text: We need to get away from feeling, in the same way,

510.text: human rights matters because of the other things it brings,

514.text: or women's rights matters for the other things it brings.

517.text: Why should we get away from those arguments?

520.text: Because they're very dangerous. If we set about saying,

522.text: for example, torture is wrong because it doesn't extract

527.text: good information, or we say, you need women's rights

532.text: because it stimulates economic growth by doubling the size of the work force,

537.text: you leave yourself open to the position where

538.text: the government of North Korea can turn around and say,

540.text: "Well actually, we're having a lot of success extracting

543.text: good information with our torture at the moment,"

546.text: or the government of Saudi Arabia to say, "Well,

548.text: our economic growth's okay, thank you very much,

551.text: so maybe we don't need to go ahead with this program on women's rights."

556.text: The point about democracy is not instrumental.

559.text: It's not about the things that it brings.

562.text: The point about democracy is not that it delivers

565.text: legitimate, effective, prosperous rule of law.

571.text: It's not that it guarantees peace with itself or with its neighbors.

576.text: The point about democracy is intrinsic.

579.text: Democracy matters because it reflects an idea of equality

584.text: and an idea of liberty. It reflects an idea of dignity,

588.text: the dignity of the individual, the idea that each individual

592.text: should have an equal vote, an equal say,

596.text: in the formation of their government.

600.text: But if we're really to make democracy vigorous again,

604.text: if we're ready to revivify it, we need to get involved

606.text: in a new project of the citizens and the politicians.

611.text: Democracy is not simply a question of structures.

616.text: It is a state of mind. It is an activity.

620.text: And part of that activity is honesty.

764.text: the honesty in language, the local democracy,

771.text: For politicians to be honest, the public needs to allow them to be honest,

776.text: and the media, which mediates between the politicians

779.text: and the public, needs to allow those politicians to be honest.

784.text: If local democracy is to flourish, it is about the active

787.text: and informed engagement of every citizen.

791.text: In other words, if democracy is to be rebuilt,

796.text: is to become again vigorous and vibrant,

800.text: it is necessary not just for the public

803.text: to learn to trust their politicians,

806.text: but for the politicians to learn to trust the public.
